channel.title: NPR Topics: Economy
channel.description: NPR news on the U.S. and world economy, the World Bank, and Federal Reserve. Commentary on economic trends. Subscribe to NPR Economy podcasts and RSS feeds.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Homeowners stall Connecticut's push for more housing
item.description: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.content:encoded: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.dc:creator: Molly Ingram

item.title: Consumers' collective feeling about the economy isn't matching our spending behavior
item.description: There's a puzzling split between how consumers overall feel about the economy and how they're acting, how much they are spending overall. Normally spending and feelings go together. Not right now.
item.content:encoded: There's a puzzling split between how consumers overall feel about the economy and how they're acting, how much they are spending overall. Normally spending and feelings go together. Not right now.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gonzalez

item.title: Inflation cools slightly in November as worries about affordability grip Americans
item.description: The cost of living in November was up 2.7% from a year ago, according to a report Thursday from the Labor Department. That's a smaller annual increase than for the 12 months ending in September.
item.content:encoded:
The cost of living in November was up 2.7% from a year ago, according to a report Thursday from the Labor Department. That's a smaller annual increase than for the 12 months ending in September.

(Image credit: Charly Triballeau)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: A new poll finds voters souring on Trump's handling of the economy
item.description: A new NPR/PBS News/Marist Poll finds Americans deeply pessimistic about their economic outlook, with more than six in 10 saying the economy is not working for them personally.
item.content:encoded: A new NPR/PBS News/Marist Poll finds Americans deeply pessimistic about their economic outlook, with more than six in 10 saying the economy is not working for them personally.
item.dc:creator: Elena Moore

item.title: Overdue jobs report shows the unemployment rate is inching up
item.description: An overdue report from the Labor Department shows signs of weakness in the job market. US employers added just 64,000 jobs last month, and the unemployment rate rose to its highest level in more than four years.
item.content:encoded: An overdue report from the Labor Department shows signs of weakness in the job market. US employers added just 64,000 jobs last month, and the unemployment rate rose to its highest level in more than four years.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: The U.S. added just 64,000 jobs in November -- a sign the labor market is slowing
item.description: Hiring cooled this fall, according to delayed figures released by the Labor Department Tuesday. Employers added 64,000 jobs in November as the unemployment rate rose to 4.6%.
item.content:encoded:
Hiring cooled this fall, according to delayed figures released by the Labor Department Tuesday. Employers added 64,000 jobs in November as the unemployment rate rose to 4.6%.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: The Warner Bros. Curse
item.description: Warner Bros. has a history of disastrous mergers and acquisitions. Can they avoid another bad sequel as Netflix and Paramount battle to buy it?
item.content:encoded:
Warner Bros. has a history of disastrous mergers and acquisitions. Can they avoid another bad sequel as Netflix and Paramount battle to buy it?

(Image credit: Mario Tama)
item.dc:creator: Greg Rosalsky

item.title: How do chain restaurants offer unlimited pasta in this economy?
item.description: Inflation, rising food prices and the high cost of living have been top of mind for consumers all year. But then Olive Garden offers an unlimited pasta meal, or a chain steakhouse restaurant sells a steak dinner with two sides for less than 30 bucks. So, how are chains able to keep prices as low as they do in this economy?
item.content:encoded:
Inflation, rising food prices and the high cost of living have been top of mind for consumers all year. But then Olive Garden offers an unlimited pasta meal, or a chain steakhouse restaurant sells a steak dinner with two sides for less than 30 bucks. So, how are chains able to keep prices as low as they do in this economy?

(Image credit: Keren Carrión)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: Why tariffs on Chinese imports matter for Mexican trade with the U.S.
item.description: NPR's Rob Schmitz talks with Antonio Ortiz Mena of Georgetown University about Mexico's recently imposed tariffs on Chinese imports and why they matter in relation to Mexican trade with the U.S.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Rob Schmitz talks with Antonio Ortiz Mena of Georgetown University about Mexico's recently imposed tariffs on Chinese imports and why they matter in relation to Mexican trade with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: Should you use buy now, pay later? Experts share 4 tips to know
item.description: The payment option is booming among online holiday shoppers this year. But like any form of credit, it comes with drawbacks. Here's how to use BNPL responsibly — and protect yourself from risk.
item.content:encoded: The payment option is booming among online holiday shoppers this year. But like any form of credit, it comes with drawbacks. Here's how to use BNPL responsibly — and protect yourself from risk.
item.dc:creator: Vito Emanuel
